channel.title: Paws and Claws
channel.description: Here to rescue those who can't rescue themselves

item.title: Contact Us
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: To contact Take Me Home, email takeMeHome@xyz.com. We do our best to answer your calls, but as we all have regular jobs, you may need to leave us a message by email. If you email us, please tell us your name and how to contact you. If you are interested in adoption a particular dog or cat, please include the name of the pet in your email. You are welcome to leave more information about yourself in your email. We check our messages several times a day. You can also visit us on Facebook and become our Facebook friend. Our Facebook is Take Me Home Rescue. We welcome your friendship on our page.

item.title: The Journey Begins
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for joining me!
Good company in a journey makes the way seem shorter. — Izaak Walton

item.title: The Little Rascal
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
Rascal: 7 years old, neutered male, yellow Lab, 75 lbs.

Rascal was “surrendered” to us by his owner, who had lost his home to foreclosure. He’s great with other dogs, and he loves people, going for walks, running, and playing Frisbee. He’s good with children and enjoys riding in the car. He has a cute habit of standing on his haunches and gently giving you his front paws. Rascal shouldn’t go to a home with cats, because he tends to chase them. Our vet has taken care of all Rascal's vaccinations, removed his dewclaws, and microchipped him. He’d make a wonderful family dog.

If you’re interested in Rascal, please call Donna at Paws and Claws —(555) 555-5555.

item.title: Cindy Lou Who
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
CINDY: 3 years old, spayed female, Shepherd mix, 40 lbs.

Cindy came to us because her family was splitting up. She's never gotten the attention a young dog needs. Cindy is super playful. She loves toys, and her favorite game is fetch. She’s a smart cookie and adapts well to positive training. She already knows “sit,” “down,” “stay,” “shake,” and “sit pretty,” and she’s learning more fun tricks like “roll over.” Cindy is house-trained, rides well in the car, and enjoys being brushed and groomed. She behaves well around the house and respects her boundaries. This special girl needs an adult-only home with people who have experience with large dogs, so she can continue to develop into a well-adjusted dog. Cindy needs someone who’ll give her very clear rules, lots of love, and plenty of exercise. In return, she’ll be your loyal friend for life.

For information about Cindy, call Donna at Paws and Claws: (555) 555-5555.

item.title: Cuteness Overload
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
6 months old, spayed female domestic shorthairs
Snowball: 4lbs, Sally: 5lbs

If you're looking to bring some love and joy into your home, look no further than these two girls. They’re 6-month-old rescues—amazingly sweet and loving. They’re affectionate (big-time purrers and cuddlers), playful, and endlessly entertaining. They are also healthy, have had their shots, have been spayed, and are litterbox trained. Because they’ve bonded to each other, we’d like to keep them together

For information about Snowball & Sally, call Jessica at Paws and Claws: (555) 555-5555.

item.title: snowball_sally
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: asf

item.title: The Astro-Physicist
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
ASTRO: 2 years old, neutered male, domestic shorthair, 12 lbs.

Astro can thank his lucky stars, because after a car hit him, he made it out of the vet hospital in Springfield and found a temporary home with us. Astro’s a little nervous, but once he settles down, he loves people to pet him. He’s lean and lanky, and even though we think he’s fit to run a kitty marathon, he weighs almost 12 pounds!

Astro is a sweetheart, but he’s very scared right now. Come meet with him and see what a great guy he can be. Maybe you can give him his forever home!

For information about Astro, call Jake at Paws and Claws: (555) 555-5555.

item.title: Dogs and Cats for Adoption
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: afsd

item.title: Adoption Info
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: Our shelter continues to grow and improve. Drop by and get to know us better! If you see a cat on this Web site who interests you, please call the number shown to make arrangements to meet the dog or cat. If you get an answering machine, please leave a message including the name of the pet. (If you email us, please include your phone number.) The adoption procedure is very thorough. You will be required to fill out an application and agree to an adoption contract. (Sorry, these are not available on-line at this time.) You will also be given information about caring for your new companion, including the many facets of caring for a new pet and introducing the pet to a new environment. We want your adoption to be a success! Please do not try to pick a pet based on color, breed, or the memory of a pet you once loved. It is very important to let the pet pick you, rather than the other way around, because pets go by scent and are naturally attracted to certain people while indifferent to others. Unfortunately, we are not currently equipped to do long-distance adoptions. Continued Care We can become the legal guardian of your pet in the event of your possible illness or death. Many times, pet owners can bequeath their animals to us in a will, and we'll make sure they find a wonderful new home.

item.title: Services
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: VOLUNTEERS: We can always use a hand! You can help by caring for our homeless cats and dogs, keeping the shelter clean, helping us raise funds, or fostering pets. Find out about becoming a Take Me Home volunteer. SPAY/NEUTER CLINIC: Spaying or neutering your pet is the best way to stop the flood of homeless animals in Springfield. Our modern spay and neuter clinic has a top-notch professional team. ANIMAL RESCUE: Our animals come to us in many ways. We ensure the pets general health is good and either keep it in our shelter, or place it into a foster home. REHABILITATION: Take Me Home retrains animals with behavioral problems to be better companions in their new homes. And after the adoption, we’re here to help with behavior consultations, training classes, and more.

item.title: Support Us
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: We need your help! Help us in our mission to find loving homes for deserving dogs and cats. When you register with Ralphs and select Take Me Home Rescue as your cause, a portion of every purchase you make through Ralphs goes to our organization. It only takes a minute to register... and from then on each Ralphs shopping you will have the satisfaction in knowing that you are making a difference in the lives of many sweet pets. Click here to register with Ralphs. Select Take Me Home Rescue as your cause (code 34567) You may also donate using Paypal.

item.title: Fees
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
Thank you so much for looking into adoption for your next pet! With as many as 50 dogs and cats available at any given time and over 1,300 animals adopted annually, we seek to promote no-kill alternatives through our innovative programs. All of the animals receive full medical and behavioral evaluations, and our staff works with you to help your new pet feel comfortable in its new home. To cover these expenses, there is a small fee associated with the pet adoption. Adoption fees are donations to help support the care of our animals. If you were to pay a similar fee for an animal through a breeder or pet store, not only would you not be helping a pet in need, you’d be paying for intentional breeding that has led to an overpopulation of pets. Adoption fees help cover the medical care of the animal while he or she waits for a new home, as well as food and transportation costs. These fees help to provide care for the other animals in the rescue group who may have medical bills that are much higher than any possible adoption fee. The money also acts as a donation to help support our organization as a whole, allowing the group to continue its efforts to rescue and rehome pets. The $100 Adoption fee includes:
  • Veterinary wellness visit and exam (worth $50-100)
  • Spaying or neutering (worth $150-300)
  • Distemper vaccination (worth $20-30×2)
  • Rabies vaccination (worth $15-25)
  • Heartworm test (for dogs) (worth $15-35)
  • Feline Leukemia/FIV test (for cats) (worth $30-50)
  • Flea/tick treatment (worth $50-200)

item.title: Application Form
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: Sorry, these are not available on-line at this time Thank you for being interested in adopting a pet from us! The following information is required so that we can assist you in the selection of your new dog or cat. This form and consultation with a representative is designed to help us determine if the adoption is in the animal’s best interest, and to assist you in finding the dog or cat most compatible with your household and lifestyle. CLICK HERE TO SEE MORE THAN 100 DOGS AND CATS AVAILABLE FOR ADOPTION IN THE SPRINGFIELD AREA.

item.title: Volunteers
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
Without our dedicated group of volunteers, Take Me Home couldn't provide such outstanding care for animals. Take Me Home volunteers are involved in almost all aspects of the shelter—providing hands-on care to the shelter animals, keeping the shelter clean, bottle-feeding motherless kittens and puppies, answering phones, participating in events and fund-raisers, and even fostering animals in their own homes. Our volunteer program lets individuals or groups get involved according to their own interests and talents. The Junior Volunteer program is for teens aged 13 to 15, and the Adult Volunteer program is for ages 16 and older. Both offer an opportunity to work on behalf of the shelter's animals and to make a positive impact on Springfield. Through our Kids' Programs, children 9 to 12 can also help our animals. If you're interested in becoming a volunteer, just complete these four simple steps:
  1. Submit a Volunteer Application. Click here to download it.
  2. Read the Volunteer Handbook (available at the shelter).
  3. Register for and attend a Volunteer Orientation. To register, call (555) 555-1212.
  4. Complete your first hour of service training with an approved Volunteer Mentor.

item.title: Animal Rescue
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
<u>Animal Rescue and Transfers</u>
Our animals come from a number of places—overcrowded area shelters, surrenders from local families that can no longer care for their dog or cat, and feral rescues. We focus on giving homeless, abandoned, and sometimes abused animals a second chance at a healthy, happy life with a caring guardian.

item.title: Spay/Neuter Clinic
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
<u>Medical and Spay/Neuter Clinic</u>
Take Me Home's on-site veterinary team assesses the health of each animal and provides appropriate treatment and vaccinations. In addition, we spay or neuter all the animals, so that more animals don't end up in shelters.

item.title: Rehab and Training
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded:
<u>Rehabilitation & Training</u>
While at Take Me Home, animals that have behavioral issues are retrained and rehabilitated to become better companions in their new homes. After the adoption, Take Me Home is always there to help with behavior consultations, "positive reinforcement" dog and cat training classes, and any other advice an adopter may need.

item.title: Our Pets Are Looking for Someone like You
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: Because of tough economic times, fewer people can afford to keep their pets. So the number of homeless animals in and around Springfield is increasing dramatically. Take Me Home is a nonprofit, no-kill animal shelter serving the Springfield area. Our mission is to give these homeless animals a second chance through our rescue, shelter, and adoption programs. We were founded in 1990 with a few simple goals: sa ve and place cats and dogs in new homes, and educate the public about spaying and neutering their pets. We’re now one of the largest no-kill shelters in the state! Each year, Take Me Home helps more than 1,300 cats and dogs find permanent homes. Take Me Home strives to provide a safe and healthy transition home to the animals we rescue and place. We hope our mission inspires others in the Springfield community to learn more about animal needs and how to care for and live with a healthy and happy pet. For more information, click any topic.

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: dthecsguy
item.content:encoded: Take Me Home is a nonprofit, no-kill animal shelter serving the Springfield area. Our mission is to give homeless animals a second chance through our rescue, shelter, and adoption programs. Founded in 1990, we have a few simple goals: save and re-home cats and dogs, and educate the public about spaying and neutering their pets. We're now one of the largest no-kill shelters in the state! Each year Take Me Home helps more than 1,300 cats and dogs find permanent homes. Where do these animals come from? About 40% are owner surrenders, and the other 60% are animals we rescue from shelters that euthanize. We have a dedicated staff of 6 (half are part-time). And our 50-plus volunteers are our backbone (thank you volunteers and donors!). Many of the rescued animals who come to Take Me Home get more love and attention in our shelter than they've ever known before.
